title: 'Chemo robs you of your reflection as the head staring back at you isn't your own'
text:

Chemo - one of the first thing that probably enters your head is, ‘will I lose my hair’.

My first thought was obviously ‘Oh my god, I’m going to die’.

Once my breast cancer nurse had explained that they were going to do everything they could to get rid of the bugger, she went on to explain that I’d need surgery, chemo and possible radiotherapy.

Truthfully at that point, I did not care in the slightest about losing my breasts or my hair.

I was just 32 years old and I bloody wanted to live - no matter the deformities and the baldness.

(Image: Roisin Pelan)

(Image: Roisin Pelan)

As time went on though, met reflection no longer reflected me. I was bloated from steroids and carb cravings, bald from chemo and boobless from surgery.

I was heartbroken when I saw myself getting out of the shower…who the bloody hell was that looking back at me?

People would sometimes say (with the best of intentions), “but at least you’re still here Ro”.

I’d feel almost guilty for feeling sorry for myself sometimes.

I’d considered trying out the cold cap but I was told it would probably still fall out anyway and my younger brother had tried it for his Hodgkin’s lymphoma years ago.

(Image: Roisin Pelan)

(Image: Roisin Pelan)

He’d told me it felt like eating 10 ice-creams at once. So I just thought, sod it, whip the hair off.

One of my friends who was a hairdresser whopped it off in a pub filled with family and friends and it was actually a really bloody lovely night- emotional but lovely.

We raised money for CRUK and donated my hair to The little Princess Trust who make real hair wigs for children affected by cancer.

It felt good to do something good out of something so utterly shit.

One of the good things about hair loss is literally NO HAIR. Not good for dry eyes and drippy nostrils but amazing for legs, arms and undies. I was so bloody smooth.

(Image: Roisin Pelan)

Eventually, my hair started to grow back, I was like a dandelion.

My little babe, Ivy and me competed for who’s hair could grow the quickest - she won.

I was so protective over my precious hair, winced when the hairdresser trimmed it but in the end, I just wanted to try every style I could as it grew out.

Admittedly, it was burned by bleach and colour but eventually, I almost had a bob.

Woooohooo, I love the feeling of my hair blowing in the wind and it felt amazing.

(Image: Roisin Pelan)

Then came the recurrence and I knew I had to do it all again.

I felt so sad that Ivy was three this time and she’d see the difference in mummy.

We explained that I had a naughty lump and I had to take some medicine which would make my hair fall out to get rid of it.

We asked if she’d like to cut it off for me and she did. Our little dreamboat.

I mastered the turban this time and found an absolutely brilliant wig and in all honesty, it wasn’t so bad.

(Image: Roisin Pelan)

I think the worst part for me is growing it through all the awkward stages again - the dandelion, the mullet, the Worzel.

This time, I’m taking super precious care of my hair. I’ve not had any colour on it yet - and I’m amazingly not grey.

I’ve been using the super whoop ass Dyson hairdryer and OMG, I love it.

It is pricey - but there’s lots of different attachments on it - one for a sensitive scalp. yay.

It also dries mine and Ivy’s hair faster than lightning. I love it.

My advice for people growing their hair back is - shave it twice when your fluff starts to appear.

I know, I know, it’s precious hair but it grows back so much thicker and shinier.

There are so many lovely wigs and headscarves out there now. You will be fine.
description: Mum, author and Mirror columnist Roisin Pelan lifts the lid on how it really feels to lose your hair when you're being treated for cancer
